unnormalised: Heads up, folks planning trips or calls overseas! The India Meteorological Department (IMD) just announced they're sticking to Indian Standard Time (IST), which, as most of us know, is GMT+5:30. So, if you're scheduling that video call with your cousin in the US, remember the time difference! East Coast peeps are typically GMT-5, so that's a whopping 10.5 hours behind us.
normalised: Heads up, folks planning trips or calls overseas! The India Meteorological Department (I-M-D) just announced they're sticking to Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which, as most of us know, is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. So, if you're scheduling that video call with your cousin in the U-S, remember the time difference! East Coast peeps are typically G-M-T minus five, so that's a whopping ten and a half hours behind us.

unnormalised: Confusing, right? Let's say it's 2 PM IST here in Mumbai. That makes it 4:30 AM in New York! And for those calling relatives in London, which operates on GMT during standard time and GMT+1 during British Summer Time (BST), it's either 6.5 hours or 5.5 hours behind us. Remember to double-check depending on the time of year and whether they are observing daylight savings time.
normalised: Confusing, right? Let's say it's two P-M I-S-T here in Mumbai. That makes it four thirty A-M in New York! And for those calling relatives in London, which operates on G-M-T during standard time and G-M-T plus one during British Summer Time (B-S-T), it's either six and a half hours or five and a half hours behind us. Remember to double-check depending on the time of year and whether they are observing daylight savings time.

unnormalised: The IMD also clarified that they will be releasing updates on any potential shifts related to daylight saving time in the future. Though India doesn't currently observe DST, there's been chatter about it for energy saving purposes, so keep an eye out. They'll probably announce it a month or so in advance, I would reckon.
normalised: The I-M-D also clarified that they will be releasing updates on any potential shifts related to daylight saving time in the future. Though India doesn't currently observe D-S-T, there's been chatter about it for energy saving purposes, so keep an eye out. They'll probably announce it a month or so in advance, I would reckon.

unnormalised: For folks dealing with Australia, Sydney is on AEDT, which is GMT+11. That means they're 5.5 hours ahead of IST. So a 10 AM meeting here is a 3:30 PM meeting there. Basically, always Google it! It's the easiest way to not mess up. No one wants to wake someone up in the middle of the night!
normalised: For folks dealing with Australia, Sydney is on A-E-D-T, which is G-M-T plus eleven. That means they're five and a half hours ahead of I-S-T. So a ten A-M meeting here is a three thirty P-M meeting there. Basically, always Google it! It's the easiest way to not mess up. No one wants to wake someone up in the middle of the night!

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Time zones are tricky! Always use a time zone converter or your phone's world clock to avoid accidentally scheduling a meeting at 3 AM their time. Happy travels and happy calling! Just remember to double check the hours, specially with those awkward half-hour differences like IST and ACDT!
